questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the office because of persistent upper back tenderness and discomfort for the past 2 months. She mentions that she works as a jeweler and spends several hours per day hunched over her work. Medical history is remarkable for advanced osteoporosis. Physical examination reveals a prominent left transverse process of T6. The transverse processes become more symmetrical in extension. The patient is set up for facilitated positional release (FPR). She is seated upright, and a downward compressive force is applied to her shoulders. The most appropriate subsequent patient positioning is

choices.text: flexion with left rotation and left sidebending
extension with left rotation and left sidebending
neutral with left rotation and right sidebending
extension with left rotation and right sidebending
flexion with right rotation and right sidebending

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While positioning the patient's T6 segment in left rotation and left sidebending is part of FPR and may induce release, flexing the dysfunctional segment moves it towards its restrictive barrier, which is not a component of FPR.

B) CORRECT:

In indirect treatment methods such as FPR, which are gentler and suitable for patients who are at increased risk of pathologic fractures (e.g., due to advanced osteoporosis), the focus is on moving tissues and/or joints away from the restrictive barrier (i.e., into the position of ease) to enhance joint function and alleviate tissue tension. In FPR, the dysfunctional segment is first brought to a neutral position; an activating force such as compression or torsion is then introduced. The segment is subsequently moved into its position of ease, which, in this case of T6 ERLSL dysfunction, is extension with left rotation and left sidebending. The position is held for 3–5 seconds before being released.

The treatment sequence of FPR can be remembered as "neutral, compress, ease."
Image Description:

Law I: With the spine starting in a neutral position (i.e., without flexion or extension), sidebending occurs before rotation. Sidebending and rotation then happen to the opposite sides.

Law II: With the spine starting in a nonneutral position (i.e., with flexion or extension) rotation occurs before sidebending. Sidebending and rotation then happen to the same side.

C) INCORRECT:

According to Fryette's first law, rotation and sidebending occur to opposite sides when the thoracic spine is in a neutral position, which is why this would be the correct positioning for a patient with a T6 NRLSL somatic dysfunction. However, this patient's restriction to rotation improves with extension, indicating that the segment is in a nonneutral position. Moreover, in a type 1 dysfunction, three or more adjacent segments are typically involved.

D) INCORRECT:

Rotation and sidebending occur to the same side when the thoracic spine is in a nonneutral position (i.e., extension or flexion). Rotating and sidebending to opposite sides is, therefore, not consistent with FPR.

E) INCORRECT:

Flexion with right rotation and right sidebending would move this patient's dysfunctional T6 segment towards its restrictive barrier. This positioning is done in direct treatment methods (e.g., high-velocity low-amplitude techniques), which are typically avoided in patients at increased risk of pathologic fractures (e.g., due to advanced osteoporosis).
questions.hint: Rotation of the thoracic spine is assessed by placing the thumbs over the transverse processes of each segment. If the left transverse process is more prominent than the right, the segment is rotated left. If the symmetry is restored in extension, this suggests that the segment is extended. According to Fryette's second law, rotation and sidebending occur to the same side when the thoracic spine is in a nonneutral position, which is why this patient can be diagnosed with a T6 ERLSL somatic dysfunction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of midthoracic pain that is localized to the area between the shoulder blades. The pain worsens when she sits for long periods, which she has been doing frequently during her work as a medical editor. Structural examination reveals a prominent left transverse process that becomes more prominent in flexion. The spinous process of the affected vertebra is palpated halfway between the transverse processes of T6 and T7. The most likely diagnosis is

choices.text: T7 extended, rotated right, sidebent right
T7 neutral, sidebent left, rotated left
T7 flexed, rotated left, sidebent right
T6 neutral, sidebent right, rotated left
T6 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right
T6 extended, rotated left, sidebent left

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the rule of threes, the spinous processes of vertebrae T4–T6 and T11 are located halfway between their corresponding transverse processes and the transverse processes one segment below, which means that this patient's dysfunction is at T6, not T7. Furthermore, if the affected vertebra were rotated right, the right transverse process would be more prominent than the left.

B) INCORRECT:

According to the rule of threes, the spinous processes of vertebrae T4–T6 and T11 are located halfway between their corresponding transverse processes and the transverse processes one segment below, which means that this patient's dysfunction is at T6, not T7. Furthermore, Fryette's first law states that rotation and sidebending occur to opposite sides when the thoracic spine is in a neutral position. There are no neutral dysfunctions of the thoracic spine with sidebending and rotation to the same side. This patient's somatic dysfunction is exacerbated by flexion, indicating that it is a nonneutral or type 2 dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

According to the rule of threes, the spinous processes of vertebrae T4–T6 and T11 are located halfway between their corresponding transverse processes and the transverse processes one segment below, which means that this patient's dysfunction is at T6, not T7. Somatic dysfunctions are always named based on freedom of motion, which, in this patient's dysfunction, is not flexion. Furthermore, Fryette's second law states that rotation and sidebending occur to the same side when the thoracic spine is in a nonneutral position. There are no nonneutral dysfunctions of the thoracic spine with sidebending and rotation to opposite sides.

D) INCORRECT:

According to Fryette's first law, rotation and sidebending occur to opposite sides when the thoracic spine is in a neutral position, which is why this diagnosis would be correct if the asymmetry did not resolve in flexion or extension (i.e., neutral or type 1 dysfunction). However, this patient's somatic dysfunction is exacerbated in flexion, indicating a nonneutral or type 2 dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Somatic dysfunctions are always named based on freedom of motion, which, in this patient's dysfunction, is not flexion. Furthermore, if the affected vertebra were rotated right, the right transverse process would be more prominent than the left.

F) CORRECT:

According to the rule of threes, the spinous processes of vertebrae T4–T6 and T11 are located halfway between their corresponding transverse processes and the transverse processes one segment below, which means that this patient's dysfunction is at T6. The vertebra has a more prominent left than right transverse process in a neutral position, indicating that it is rotated left. Flexion of the spine exacerbates the left rotation, indicating that this is a nonneutral or type 2 dysfunction and that the asymmetry will improve or resolve in extension, the segment's direction of ease. Additionally, Fryette's second law states that rotation and sidebending occur toward the same side when the thoracic spine is in a nonneutral position. T6 ERLSL is the correct diagnosis.

Note that Fryette's first law and Fryette's second law apply to the thoracic and lumbar spine.
questions.hint: The rule of threes describes the positional relationship between the spinous and transverse processes in the thoracic spine and can be used to determine which vertebra is affected. To diagnose this patient's somatic dysfunction, Fryette's second law should be applied.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of midthoracic pain that is localized to the area between the shoulder blades. The pain worsens when she sits for long periods, which she has been doing frequently while working as a Medical Editor. Structural examination reveals a prominent left transverse process that becomes more prominent in flexion. The spinous process of the affected vertebra is palpated halfway between the transverse processes of T6 and T7. You diagnose a T6 extended, rotated left, sidebent left somatic dysfunction and decide to treat with facilitated positional release (FPR). After straightening the spinal curve and applying an activating force, the next step of FPR involves

choices.text: application of a thrust directed toward right sidebending and right rotation
passive extension with left sidebending and left rotation
active muscle contraction toward left sidebending and left rotation
passive flexion with left sidebending and left rotation
passive flexion with right sidebending and right rotation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Engaging the restrictive barrier (right sidebending and right rotation) followed by the application of a quick thrust through the restrictive barrier is consistent with high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) technique. Moving the affected segment toward its restrictive barrier or applying a thrust is not a component of FPR.

B) CORRECT:

Facilitated positional release (FPR) is a passive, indirect myofascial technique that involves placing the affected area in a neutral position and then applying an activating force (often downward compression) to facilitate the relaxation of tissues and muscles. The segment is subsequently moved into its position of ease and is held for 3–5 seconds before release and reevaluation. As this patient has a T6 extended, rotated left, sidebent left dysfunction, application of FPR involves applying downward compression on a neutral spine and then moving the segments into left sidebending and left rotation, which is the position of ease.

C) INCORRECT:

Active muscle contraction toward the direction of ease (left sidebending and left rotation) is a component of muscle energy technique. Unlike FPR, all muscle energy techniques are active techniques, meaning that they require the patient to contract their muscles. Furthermore, muscle energy is almost always a direct form of osteopathic treatment, in which the restrictive barrier must initially be engaged.

D) INCORRECT:

While positioning the patient's T6 segment in left sidebending and left rotation is part of FPR and may induce release, flexing the dysfunctional segment moves it toward its restrictive barrier, which is not a component of FPR.

E) INCORRECT:

Still technique involves applying an activating force while moving the segment toward its restrictive barrier (flexion with right sidebending and right rotation). Moving the affected segment toward its restrictive barrier is not a component of FPR.
questions.hint: The treatment sequence of FPR can be remembered as “neutral, compress, ease.”

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 4-day history of localized pain in the mid-back. He does parkour regularly and often practices complex maneuvers and jumps. A neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Structural examination reveals that the right transverse process of the affected vertebra is more posterior than the left; the asymmetry disappears when he bends forward. The spinous process of the affected vertebra is located on the level of the T10 transverse process. The most likely diagnosis is

choices.text: T10 flexed, rotated left, sidebent right
T11 extended, rotated left, sidebent right
T11 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left
T10 extended, rotated right, sidebent right
T9 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right
T9 extended, rotated right, sidebent left

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The spinous process palpated on the level of the T10 transverse process does not belong to T10. Additionally, Fryette's second law states that in a nonneutral position (i.e., flexion or extension) of the thoracic spine, rotation and sidebending occur toward the same side. Furthermore, if the affected vertebra were rotated left, then the left transverse process would be more prominent than the right.

B) INCORRECT:

The spinous process palpated on the level of the T10 transverse process does not belong to T11. Additionally, Fryette's second law states that, in a nonneutral position (i.e., flexion or extension) of the thoracic spine, rotation and sidebending occur toward the same side. Furthermore, somatic dysfunctions are always named based on freedom of motion, which, in this patient's dysfunction, is not extension. If the affected vertebra were rotated left, then the left transverse process would be more prominent than the right.

C) INCORRECT:

The spinous process palpated on the level of the T10 transverse process does not belong to T11. Furthermore, if the affected vertebra were rotated left, then the left transverse process would be more prominent than the right.

D) INCORRECT:

The spinous process palpated on the level of the T10 transverse process does not belong to T10. Furthermore, somatic dysfunctions are always named based on freedom of motion, which, in this patient's dysfunction, is not extension.

E) CORRECT:

According to the rule of threes, the spinous processes of vertebrae T7–T10 are located one segment below the corresponding transverse processes. This patient's dysfunction is, therefore, at T9. The affected vertebra has a more prominent (posterior) right than left transverse process in a neutral position, indicating that it is rotated right. The asymmetry resolves in flexion, which suggests that the segment is flexed (i.e., nonneutral or type 2 dysfunction). Finally, Fryette's second law states that rotation and sidebending occur toward the same side when the thoracic spine is in a nonneutral position. T9 FRRSR is the correct diagnosis.

Note that Fryette's first law and Fryette's second law apply to the thoracic and lumbar spine.

F) INCORRECT:

Fryette's second law states that, in a nonneutral position (i.e., flexion or extension) of the thoracic spine, rotation and sidebending occur toward the same side. Furthermore, somatic dysfunctions are always named based on freedom of motion, which, in this patient's dysfunction, is not extension.
questions.hint: The rule of threes describes the relationship between the spinous and transverse processes in the thoracic spine and can be used to determine which vertebra is affected. To diagnose this patient's somatic dysfunction, Fryette's second law should be applied.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 4-day history of localized pain in the mid-back. He does parkour regularly and often practices complex maneuvers and jumps. A neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Structural examination reveals that the right transverse process of the affected vertebra is more posterior than the left; the asymmetry disappears when he bends forward. The spinous process of the affected vertebra is located on the level of the T10 transverse process. The patient is diagnosed with a T9 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right (T9 FRRSR) somatic dysfunction. The patient is prepared for treatment with facilitated positional release (FPR). He is seated upright and a downward compressive force is applied to his shoulders. The most appropriate next step is to position the segment in

choices.text: neutral with right sidebending and left rotatation
flexion with left rotation and left sidebending
flexion with right rotation and right sidebending
neutral with left sidebending and right rotatation
extension with right rotation and right sidebending
extension with left rotation and left sidebending

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

FPR involves positioning the dysfunctional segment into the position of ease, which would not be achieved in the neutral position as this patient has a nonneutral somatic dysfunction (T9 FRRSR).

B) INCORRECT:

While positioning the patient's T9 segment in flexion is part of FPR and may induce release, left rotation and sidebending of the dysfunctional segment moves it towards its restrictive barrier, which is not a component of FPR.

C) CORRECT:

FPR is an indirect treatment method in which the affected area is moved into the position of ease to enhance joint function and alleviate tissue tension. In FPR to the spine, the dysfunctional segment is first placed in a neutral position before an activating force such as compression is applied. The segment is subsequently moved into its position of ease. In this patient's dysfunctions (T9 FRRSR), the position of ease is in flexion with right rotation and right sidebending. This position is held for 3–5 seconds before being released.

D) INCORRECT:

FPR involves positioning the dysfunctional segment into the position of ease, which would not be achieved in the neutral position as this patient has a nonneutral somatic dysfunction (T9 FRRSR).

E) INCORRECT:

While positioning the patient's T9 segment in right rotation and right sidebending is part of FPR and may induce release, extending the dysfunctional segment moves it towards its restrictive barrier, which is not a component of FPR.

F) INCORRECT:

Positioning the patient's T9 segment in extension with left rotation and left sidebending moves it towards its restrictive barrier, which is not a component of FPR.
questions.hint: The treatment sequence of FPR can be remembered as “neutral, compress, ease.”

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of back pain for the past week. She recalls no traumatic events but mentions that he has started carrying a bigger backpack this year to hold all of his school books. Physical examination reveals:

Tenderness and muscle hypertonicity in the paravertebral tissue from the vertebral prominence to the level of the spines of the scapulae

Transverse processes that are more prominent on the right than on the left in the affected area

Asymmetry that does not realign with extension or flexion
No neurological deficits and normal muscle strength

Which of the following somatic dysfunctions is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: T3-T6 neutral, sidebent right, rotated left
T1-T3 neutral, sidebent left, rotated right
T2-T5 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left
T1-T2 flexed, rotated right, sidebent left
C7-T3 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right
C6-T3 neutral, sidebent left, rotated right

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's affected vertebrae have more prominent right than left transverse processes in a neutral position, indicating that they are rotated right rather than left. Furthermore, the spines of the scapulae are at the level of T3, which means that a somatic dysfunction affecting T4–T6 is unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

The vertebral prominence (the large spinous process of C7) and the spines of the scapulae can be used as anatomical landmarks to locate C7 and T3 respectively. The affected vertebrae have more prominent right than left transverse processes in a neutral position, indicating that they are rotated right. The asymmetry does not resolve with flexion or extension, which suggests that a type 1 dysfunction (neutral dysfunction) is present. Fryette's first law applies to the thoracic and lumbar spines and states that rotation and sidebending occur to opposite sides when in a neutral position. Therefore, T1–T3 neutral, sidebent left, rotated right (T1–T3 NSLRR) is the most likely somatic dysfunction in this patient.

Type 1 dysfunctions commonly affect 3 or more adjacent vertebrae.

C) INCORRECT:

Somatic dysfunctions are always named for their freedom of motion, and this patient's asymmetry of the transverse processes does not resolve with flexion, ruling out a flexion dysfunction. Furthermore, if this patient's affected vertebrae were rotated left, the transverse processes would be more prominent on the left than on the right. Additionally, the spines of the scapulae are at the level of T3, making it unlikely that T4 and T5 are affected.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's affected vertebrae have more prominent right than left transverse processes in a neutral position, indicating that they are rotated right. However, somatic dysfunctions are always named for their freedom of motion, and this patient's asymmetry of the transverse processes does not resolve with flexion, ruling out a flexion dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

The vertebral prominence (the large spinous process of C7) and the spines of the scapulae can be used as anatomical landmarks to locate C7 and T3 respectively, and it is possible that the C7–T3 vertebrae are affected in this patient. However, somatic dysfunctions are always named for their freedom of motion, and this patient's asymmetry of the transverse processes does not resolve with flexion, ruling out a flexion dysfunction.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's affected vertebrae have more prominent right than left transverse processes in a neutral position, indicating that they are rotated right. Furthermore, the asymmetry does not resolve with flexion or extension, suggesting that a type 1 dysfunction (neutral dysfunction) is present. Although Fryette's first law states that rotation and sidebending occur to opposite sides when the vertebrae are in a neutral position, this law does not apply to the cervical spine. In neutral dysfunctions of the cervical spine, sidebending and rotation occur to the same side. Therefore, C6–C7 cannot be neutral, sidebent left, and rotated right. Additionally, the vertebral prominence is the large spinous process of C7, making it unlikely that C6 is affected in this patient.
questions.hint: The vertebral prominence and the spines of the scapulae can be used as anatomical landmarks to determine which vertebrae are affected. To diagnose this patient's somatic dysfunction, Fryette's first law should be applied.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office with a 2-week history of left-sided chest pain that intensifies with deep breathing. On questioning, she reports a minor fall 2 weeks ago but did not seek any medical care as she felt fine. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung findings. There is restricted motion at ribs 6–9 on the left during inhalation. Treatment for this patient's somatic dysfunction should target a rib with which of the following characteristics?

choices.text: Primarily caliper motion
False rib
Primarily bucket handle motion
Primarily pump handle motion
Atypical rib

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ribs 11–12 (lower ribs) predominantly move in a caliper motion. This patient has a group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9 and therefore treatment should target a rib with different characteristics.

B) INCORRECT:

Ribs 8–12 are false ribs. This patient has a group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9 and therefore treatment should target a rib with different characteristics.

C) CORRECT:

Ribs 6–10 (middle ribs) predominantly move in a bucket handle motion, facilitating lateral expansion of the rib cage during inhalation. This movement results in the widening of the transverse diameter of the thorax. To address this patient's group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9, treatment should focus on the uppermost rib (i.e., rib 6). Rib 6 is also a true rib and a typical rib.

Ribs 1–5 (upper ribs) primarily move in a pump handle motion and ribs 11–12 (lower ribs) primarily move in a caliper motion.
Image Description:

Each rib exhibits different degrees of motion based on its position within the rib cage, e.g., ribs 1–5 predominantly engage in a pump-handle motion.

D) INCORRECT:

Ribs 1–5 (upper ribs) predominantly move in a pump handle motion. This patient has a group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9 and therefore treatment should target a rib with different characteristics.

E) INCORRECT:

Ribs 1, 2, 11, and 12 are atypical ribs. This patient has a group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9 and therefore treatment should target a rib with different characteristics.
questions.hint: Treatment of rib group dysfunction should target the key rib. In exhalation dysfunctions (i.e., restricted cephalad motion during inhalation), the key rib is the uppermost rib. Remember the mnemonic BITE (Bottom rib, Inhalation; Top rib, Exhalation).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the office with a 2-week history of progressively worsening right-sided chest discomfort that started after he fell while riding his bicycle. The pain worsens when he takes deep breaths. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals:

Normal heart and lung findings

Free cephalad rib movement during inspiration but restricted caudad movement of ribs 4–6 during exhalation on the right

Tenderness and tissue texture changes at the costochondral junction of ribs 4–6 on the right

Osteopathic manipulative treatment for this patient's somatic rib dysfunction should target

choices.text: a false rib that primarily moves in a bucket handle motion
a floating rib that primarily moves in a caliper motion
a false rib that primarily moves in a pump handle motion
a true rib that primarily moves in a pump handle motion
a true rib that primarily moves in a bucket handle motion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ribs 8–10 are the false ribs that predominantly move in a bucket handle motion. This patient has a group inhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6 and therefore treatment should target a rib with different characteristics.

B) INCORRECT:

Ribs 11–12 (lower ribs) are the floating ribs and they predominantly move in a caliper motion. This patient has a group inhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6 and therefore treatment should target a rib with different characteristics.

C) INCORRECT:

Ribs 8–12 are considered false ribs. None of the false ribs primarily move in a pump handle motion.

D) INCORRECT:

Ribs 1–5 are the true ribs that predominantly move in a pump handle motion. This patient has a group inhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6 and treatment should target the bottom rib.

E) CORRECT:

Ribs 1-7 are considered true ribs because they directly connect to the sternum via costal cartilage. Ribs 6–10 (middle ribs) primarily move in a bucket handle motion, facilitating lateral expansion of the rib cage during inhalation. This movement increases the transverse diameter of the thorax. To address this patient's group inhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6, treatment should focus on the lowest rib (i.e., rib 6). Ribs 3–10 are also considered typical ribs.

Ribs 1–5 (upper ribs) primarily move in a pump handle motion and ribs 11–12 (lower ribs) primarily move in a caliper motion.
Image Description:

Each rib exhibits different degrees of motion based on its position within the rib cage, e.g., ribs 1–5 predominantly engage in a pump-handle motion.
questions.hint: This patient's findings are consistent with a group inhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6 (rib movement is restricted during exhalation). Treatment of group dysfunctions should target the key rib, which can be identified using the BITE mnemonic: Bottom Inhalation, Top Exhalation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 1-week history of left-sided back pain that started after lifting a heavy box. On questioning, she mentions that the pain worsens with deep breathing and coughing. Past medical history is unremarkable. On examination, the ribs that primarily move in caliper motion on the left do not elevate with inhalation but descend well with exhalation. Which of the following muscles should be activated when treating this patient's somatic dysfunction using muscle energy?

choices.text: Quadratus lumborum
Latissimus dorsi
Middle scalene
Pectoralis minor
Serratus anterior

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The quadratus lumborum muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 11–12, which primarily move in caliper motion. To engage the quadratus lumborum, the patient is asked to raise the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) toward the ipsilateral shoulder for 3–5 seconds against an equal counterforce applied by the physician.

The muscle that is activated to treat an exhalation dysfunction using muscle energy depends on the key rib. The position of the key rib in group dysfunctions can be remembered using the BITE mnemonic: Bottom Inhalation, Top Exhalation. In a group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 11–12, the key rib is rib 11.
Image Description:

Each rib exhibits different degrees of motion based on its position within the rib cage, e.g., ribs 1–5 predominantly engage in a pump-handle motion.

B) INCORRECT:

The latissimus dorsi muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 9–10, which primarily move in a bucket-handle motion.

C) INCORRECT:

The middle scalene muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at rib 1, which primarily moves in a pump-handle motion.

D) INCORRECT:

The pectoralis minor muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 3–5, which primarily move in a pump-handle motion.

E) INCORRECT:

The serratus anterior muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 6–8, which primarily move in a bucket-handle motion.
questions.hint: Free movement caudad during exhalation but restricted motion cephalad during inhalation suggests an exhalation dysfunction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the office with a 2-week history of left-sided rib pain. He mentions that the pain worsens with deep inhalation and coughing. On questioning, the patient denies any trauma. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Physical examination shows normal heart and lung findings but reveals an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 9-11 on the left side. The patient is positioned for direct muscle energy treatment to correct his rib dysfunction. During the active part of this treatment, it is most appropriate to instruct the patient to

choices.text: adduct his abducted left arm
push his left arm anteriorly
push his left elbow toward the right anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
lift his left hip toward his left shoulder
turn his head to the right and lift it toward the ceiling

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Adducting the abducted arm activates the latissimus dorsi on the same side. When using muscle energy to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 9-10, the physician should instruct the patient to engage the latissimus dorsi to facilitate upward movement of the affected rib during inhalation.

B) INCORRECT:

Pushing the arm anteriorly activates the serratus anterior on the same side. The serratus anterior is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–8.

C) INCORRECT:

Pushing the elbow toward the contralateral ASIS activates the pectoralis minor on the side of the elbow. The pectoralis minor is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 3-5.

D) INCORRECT:

Lifting the hip toward the ipsilateral shoulder in the prone position activates the quadratus lumborum on the same side. The quadratus lumborum is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 11–12.

E) INCORRECT:

Turning the head away from the affected side and lifting it toward the ceiling activates the posterior scalene. The posterior scalene is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at rib 2.
questions.hint: Treatment of rib group dysfunction should target the key rib. In exhalation dysfunctions, the key rib is the uppermost rib. Remember the mnemonic BITE (Bottom rib, Inhalation; Top rib, Exhalation). In this patient with an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 9-11, the key rib is rib 9.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the office with a 2-month history of discomfort and occasional sharp pain in her upper right chest. On questioning, she reports that the pain started after she was involved in a minor car accident. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals:

Normal heart and lung sounds

Anterior parts of ribs 4–6 on the right move caudad on expiration but are restricted in cephalad movement

Increased intercostal space between ribs 3 and 4

The patient is positioned for muscle energy treatment. During the active part of this treatment, it is most appropriate to instruct the patient to

choices.text: lift her right hip toward her right shoulder
push her right elbow toward her left anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
adduct her abducted right arm
turn her head to the left and lift it toward the ceiling
push her right arm anteriorly

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lifting the hip toward the ipsilateral shoulder in the prone position activates the quadratus lumborum on the same side. The quadratus lumborum is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 11–12.

B) CORRECT:

To treat this patient's exhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6 on the right side using muscle energy, the physician should instruct the patient to engage the right pectoralis minor to promote elevation of rib 4 (i.e., the key rib) during inhalation. Moving the elbow toward the opposite anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) activates the pectoralis minor muscle, which attaches to ribs 3–5.

C) INCORRECT:

Adducting the abducted arm activates the latissimus dorsi on the same side. The latissimus dorsi is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 9–10.

D) INCORRECT:

Turning the head away from the affected side and lifting it toward the ceiling activates the posterior scalene. The posterior scalene is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at rib 2.

E) INCORRECT:

Pushing the arm anteriorly activates the serratus anterior on the same side. The serratus anterior is primarily used to treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–8.
questions.hint: Muscle energy is frequently used to treat rib exhalation dysfunctions and treatment should be targeted at the key rib. In exhalation dysfunctions, the key rib is the uppermost rib. Remember the mnemonic BITE (Bottom rib, Inhalation; Top rib, Exhalation).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the office with a 10-day history of right-sided upper back pain. She denies any recent trauma. On questioning, the patient mentions that she recently started a new job that involves prolonged periods of sitting. Past medical history reveals intermittent tension headaches. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung sounds, localized tenderness over the right anterior rib cage, and restricted sidebending of T1–6 to the right. Ribs 2–5 on the right elevate poorly with inhalation but descend well with exhalation. Which of the following muscles should be activated when treating this patient's rib somatic dysfunction?

choices.text: Iliocostalis
Serratus anterior
Pectoralis minor
Posterior scalene
Serratus posterior superior

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the iliocostalis muscle attaches to the ribs and is responsible for movement and stabilization of the vertebral column, this muscle is not primarily used to treat exhalation dysfunctions.

B) INCORRECT:

The serratus anterior muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 6–8. This patient has an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 2–5 and therefore another muscle should be activated.

C) INCORRECT:

The pectoralis minor muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 3–5. This patient has an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 2–5 and therefore another muscle should be activated.

D) CORRECT:

The posterior scalene muscle, which elevates rib 2 during inhalation, is activated to treat an exhalation dysfunction at rib 2. To engage the posterior scalene, the patient is placed in the supine position and asked to turn their head away from the affected side. They are then asked to lift their head toward the ceiling against an equal counterforce applied by the physician.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the serratus posterior superior muscle is involved in elevating the upper ribs during inspiration, this muscle is not primarily used to treat exhalation dysfunctions.
questions.hint: Treatment of a rib group dysfunction should target the key rib. In an exhalation dysfunction, the key rib is the uppermost rib. Remember the mnemonic BITE (Bottom rib, Inhalation; Top rib, Exhalation).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the office with a 3-week history of worsening chest pain that is exacerbated by coughing and deep inhalation. He reports that he was treated for pneumonia approximately 4 weeks ago. Past medical history reveals hypertension and coronary artery disease. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung findings and a rib exhalation dysfunction on the right. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Serum troponin concentration is within the reference range. The physician performs an osteopathic manipulative treatment, during which the patient is placed in the supine position with his right dorsal wrist on his forehead. The patient is then asked to take a deep breath while lifting his head toward the ceiling for 3–5 seconds against an equal counterforce applied by the physician. This technique is most appropriate to treat which of the following dysfunctions?

choices.text: Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 2–4
Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 3–5
Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–8
Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 9–10
Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 11-12

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lifting the head toward the ceiling in the supine position activates the scalene muscles (i.e., anterior, middle, and posterior scalenes). The posterior scalene facilitates rib elevation during inhalation and is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at rib 2, which is the key rib in an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 2–4.

B) INCORRECT:

The muscle used to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 3–5 is the pectoralis minor, which is activated by moving the elbow toward the opposite anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).

C) INCORRECT:

The muscle used to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 6–8 is the serratus anterior, which is activated by pushing the arm on the affected side anteriorly.

D) INCORRECT:

The muscle used to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 9–10 is the latissimus dorsi, which is activated by adducting the arm on the affected side.

E) INCORRECT:

The muscle used to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 11–12 is the quadratus lumborum, which is activated by raising the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) toward the ipsilateral shoulder.
questions.hint: The muscle used to treat a group rib dysfunctions depends on the key rib, which is the top rib in exhalation dysfunctions and the bottom rib in inhalation dysfunctions (BITE mnemonic: Bottom Inhalation, Top Exhalation).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of discomfort and tightness in her upper back that usually occurs after long periods of sitting at her desk. She denies any recent trauma or falls. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung findings. Ribs 6–9 on the left side move caudad during exhalation, but are restricted during inhalation. Which of the following muscles should be activated when treating this patient's somatic dysfunction using muscle energy?

choices.text: Latissimus dorsi
Quadratus lumborum
Serratus anterior
Scalenes
Pectoralis minor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The latissimus dorsi muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 9–10. As this patient has an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9, another muscle should be activated.

B) INCORRECT:

The quadratus lumborum muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 11–12. As this patient has an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9, another muscle should be activated.

C) CORRECT:

The muscle that is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions using muscle energy depends on the key rib. To treat an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–8, the serratus anterior muscle is activated. To engage this muscle, the patient lies supine with the dorsal wrist of the affected side across the forehead. They are then asked to push the arm of the affected side anteriorly against an equal counterforce applied by the physician.

D) INCORRECT:

The scalene muscles are activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 1–2. As this patient has an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9, another muscle should be activated.

E) INCORRECT:

The pectoralis minor muscle is activated to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 3–5. As this patient has an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 6–9, another muscle should be activated.
questions.hint: Treatment of rib group dysfunctions should target the key rib. In exhalation dysfunctions, the key rib is the uppermost rib. Remember the mnemonic BITE (Bottom rib, Inhalation; Top rib, Exhalation).

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the office with a 3-day history of lower back pain that started after attending a weight-lifting class at his gym for the first time. He reports that the pain intensifies during deep inhalation. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung findings and a rib somatic dysfunction on the left. The physician performs an osteopathic manipulative treatment, during which the patient is placed in the supine position with his left arm abducted. The patient is then asked to take a deep breath while adducting his left arm for 3–5 seconds against an equal counterforce applied by the physician. This technique is most appropriate to treat which of the following rib somatic dysfunctions?

choices.text: Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 4-6
Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 10-12
Inhalation dysfunction at ribs 1-2
Exhalation dysfunction at ribs 7-9
Inhalation dysfunction at ribs 8-10

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The key rib in an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 4–6 is rib 4. To treat rib 3, 4, or 5 exhalation dysfunctions, the physician would activate the pectoralis minor by placing the patient in the supine position and asking the patient to push the elbow on the affected side toward the opposite anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).

B) CORRECT:

Adducting the abducted arm on the affected side activates the latissimus dorsi, which is used to treat exhalation dysfunctions at ribs 9–10, to facilitate rib elevation during inhalation. Treatment of rib group dysfunctions should target the key rib. The position of the key rib in group dysfunctions can be remembered using the BITE mnemonic: Bottom Inhalation, Top Exhalation. In a group exhalation dysfunction at ribs 10–12, the key rib is rib 10.

C) INCORRECT:

To treat an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 1–2 using muscle energy, the physician would place the patient in the supine position and flex the head and neck. They would then ask the patient to inhale against an isometric counterforce posed by the physician and then increase flexion during exhalation.

D) INCORRECT:

The key rib in an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 7–9 is rib 7. To treat rib 6, 7, or 8 exhalation dysfunctions, the physician would activate the serratus anterior by placing the patient in the supine position and asking the patient to push the arm on the affected side anteriorly.

E) INCORRECT:

To treat an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 8–10 using muscle energy, the physician would place the patient with the torso and lower extremities sidebent toward the affected side. They would then ask the patient to inhale against an isometric counterforce posed by the physician and then increase sidebending during exhalation.
questions.hint: The physician uses muscle energy to activate the patient's latissimus dorsi.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of persistent upper back pain. She rates the pain as a 6 on a scale of 0 to 10. She describes the pain as dull and says it worsens with prolonged sitting. She mentions that she recently started a new job as a copy editor, and she has adjusted her chair and desk ergonomics with no improvement in her pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals paravertebral muscle tightness and restricted rotation of the thoracic spine. The spinous process of the restricted vertebra is palpated at the level of the inferior angle of the scapula with her arms resting in a neutral position. This patient most likely has a somatic dysfunction at which of the following spinal levels?

choices.text: T2
T4
T5
T7
T9
T3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The T2 vertebra corresponds anteriorly to the suprasternal notch.

B) INCORRECT:

The T4 vertebra corresponds anteriorly to the sternal angle.

C) INCORRECT:

The T5 vertebra is located midway between the inferior angle and the spine of the scapula.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's somatic dysfunction is located at the level of the inferior angle of the scapula, which corresponds to the spinous process of the T7 vertebra.

E) INCORRECT:

The T9 vertebra corresponds anteriorly to the xiphoid process.

F) INCORRECT:

The T3 vertebra corresponds to the spine of the scapula.
questions.hint: The inferior angle of the scapula can be used as an anatomical landmark to determine which vertebra is affected.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with persistent chest discomfort for the past two weeks. She reports that the pain intensifies when taking deep breaths and eases when she is not exerting herself. Additionally, she recalls a recent episode of forceful sneezing after which the chest discomfort worsened. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Her vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the right anterior chest wall during palpation. There are normal heart and lung sounds on auscultation. Osteopathic structural examination reveals:


Free bilateral cephalad rib movement, but restricted caudad movement of ribs 3–5 on the right

Lateral widening of the intercostal space between ribs 5 and 6 on the right

Which of the following describes the most appropriate muscle energy technique to treat this patient's rib dysfunction?

choices.text: The patient is flexed to the level of the dysfunctional rib. The physician follows the motion of the anterosuperior aspect of rib 5 as the patient exhales forcefully, then resists the superior motion of the rib during inhalation.

The patient is flexed and sidebent toward the dysfunctional rib. The physician follows the lateral aspect of rib 6 as the patient exhales forcefully, then resists the superior motion of the rib during inhalation.

The patient is flexed to the level of the dysfunctional rib. The physician follows the motion of the anterosuperior surface of rib 3 as the patient exhales forcefully, then resists the superior motion of the rib during inhalation.

The patient is positioned with her right forearm on her forehead, palm up, and pushes her elbow toward her left ASIS. The physician provides isometric resistance to the patient's forearm and applies inferior traction to the posterior rib angle of rib 3 as the patient inhales.

The patient is positioned with her right forearm on her forehead, palm up, and pushes her arm anteriorly. The physician provides isometric resistance to the patient's forearm and applies inferior traction to the posterior rib angle of rib 6 as the patient inhales.

The patient is positioned with her right forearm on her forehead, palm up, and pushes her elbow toward her left ASIS. The physician provides isometric resistance to the patient's forearm and applies inferior traction to the posterior rib angle of rib 5 as the patient inhales.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The described technique is the most appropriate treatment for an inhalation dysfunction at rib 5 using muscle energy. Treatment of a rib group dysfunction should target the key rib, which is the bottom rib of a rib group stuck in inhalation (i.e., rib 5). Because rib 5 primarily has a pump handle motion, the physician uses the anterosuperior surface of rib 5 as a therapeutic contact.

The position of the key rib in group dysfunctions can be remembered using the BITE mnemonic: Bottom Inhalation, Top Exhalation.

B) INCORRECT:

The described technique is the most appropriate treatment for an inhalation dysfunction at rib 6 using muscle energy. This patient has an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3–5, making another technique more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

The described technique is the most appropriate treatment for an inhalation dysfunction at rib 3 using muscle energy. Treatment of a rib group dysfunction should target the key rib, which is the bottom rib of a rib group stuck in inhalation. This patient has an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3–5, and therefore treatment should target a different rib.

D) INCORRECT:

The described technique (i.e., activation of the pectoralis minor muscle) is the most appropriate treatment for an exhalation dysfunction at rib 3 using muscle energy. This patient has an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3–5, making another technique more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

The described technique (i.e., activation of the serratus anterior muscle) is the most appropriate treatment for an exhalation dysfunction at rib 6 using muscle energy. This patient has an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3–5, making another technique more appropriate.

F) INCORRECT:

The described technique (i.e., activation of the pectoralis minor muscle) is the most appropriate treatment for an exhalation dysfunction at rib 5 using muscle energy. This patient has an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3–5, making another technique more appropriate.
questions.hint: Restricted caudad movement (i.e., exhalation) indicates an inhalation somatic dysfunction at ribs 3–5 on the right, as somatic dysfunctions are named for their freedom of movement.
